excerpt: Bhai Taru Singh was a devout Sikh farmer and martyr who supported persecuted Sikhs during the Mughal era. Arrested for aiding Sikh fighters, he refused to convert to Islam and was executed by scalping in 1745, symbolizing unwavering commitment to Sikh principles like uncut hair (kesh).

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Bhai Taru Singh was born on October 6, 1720, in Poohla (also spelled Poolha or Puhia) village near Amritsar, Punjab, into a Sandhu Jatt Sikh family. His father, Bhai Jodh Singh, died in battle when Taru was young, leaving his mother, Bibi Dharam Kaur, to raise him and his younger sister, Bibi Tar Kaur, as a widow. The family lived modestly, practicing the Sikh faith amid Mughal persecution. Taru worked as a farmer, tilling small plots of land and growing maize. He was known for his piety, frugality, and adherence to Guru Gobind Singh's teachings, including maintaining uncut hair (kesh) as a symbol of Sikh identity. As a young man, he witnessed Mughal forces attempting to abduct a poor girl, only to be thwarted by Sikh fighters. This event inspired him to formally join the Khalsa, committing to the Sikh code of conduct.

biographySections.label: Contributions/Service
biographySections.value: During the 1730s‚Äì1740s, under the oppressive rule of Mughal Governor Zakaria Khan, Sikhs faced severe persecution, including bans on farming, trade, and worship. Bhai Taru Singh and his family secretly aided Sikh revolutionaries (gursikhs) hiding in jungles and deserts, providing food, clothing, and resources from their farm earnings. Despite not being wealthy, they lived sparingly‚Äîeating coarsely ground meals and wearing homespun clothes‚Äîto support their brethren. His sister Tar Kaur assisted in grinding corn and preparing provisions. This service exemplified the Sikh principle of seva (selfless service) and dasvandh (tithing 10% of earnings to the community), sustaining the Khalsa Panth during a time of exile and guerrilla resistance against Mughal forces.

biographySections.label: Key Reforms
biographySections.value: N/A (Bhai Taru Singh was not a reformer but a practitioner; his life reinforced core Sikh reforms like the Khalsa initiation by Guru Gobind Singh in 1699, emphasizing equality, courage, and resistance to forced conversion).

biographySections.label: Compositions/Writings
biographySections.value: N/A (As a farmer and martyr, Bhai Taru Singh did not author any known writings or compositions. His legacy is preserved through oral histories, janamsakhis, and historical texts like Prachin Panth Prakash).

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: In the early 1740s, informant Akil Das (also known as Harbhagat Niranjania) spied on Taru Singh's activities and reported him to Zakaria Khan for treason. Arrested alongside his sister, Taru refused bribes or pleas for release. Imprisoned and tortured in Lahore, he was brought before the governor, where he boldly proclaimed "Waheguru ji ka Khalsa, Waheguru ji ki Fateh" (The Khalsa belongs to God, victory belongs to God). Offered freedom if he converted to Islam and cut his hair, he refused, stating his strength came from his kesh blessed by Guru Gobind Singh. On June 9, 1745, in a public spectacle at Naulakha Bazaar, Lahore, his scalp was torn off with a blade, preventing hair regrowth. Left to bleed in prison, Sikh lore recounts that Zakaria Khan suffered agony and died 22 days later after striking himself with Taru's shoes, as per Taru's curse. Taru Singh passed away on July 1, 1745, at age 24‚Äì25. His body was cremated outside Delhi Gate, Lahore.

spiritualLegacy.description: Bhai Taru Singh's martyrdom underscores the Sikh commitment to the Five Ks (including kesh) and resistance against religious coercion. His sacrifice during the Chhota Ghallughara (Lesser Holocaust) era inspired generations of Sikhs to uphold faith amid tyranny, reinforcing the Khalsa's warrior-saint ethos.
keyContributions: Sustained Sikh resistance by provisioning fighters, preventing starvation during Mughal sieges.
Symbol of unshakable devotion; his refusal to cut hair highlighted the spiritual power of Sikh symbols against forced assimilation.
Inspired gurdwaras and memorials, promoting Sikh resilience and equality (as a Jatt farmer aiding all castes).

modernRelevance.description: In contemporary times, Bhai Taru Singh's story resonates in discussions of religious freedom, identity preservation, and human rights. His martyrdom is invoked in Sikh advocacy against discrimination, such as turban bans or forced assimilation.
contemporaryImpact: Memorialized in Gurdwara Shaheed Bhai Taru Singh, Lahore (built 1762 on execution site; site of legal battles for Sikh rights in Pakistan).
Featured in media: 2007 film *The Darjeeling Limited* (print depiction); 2018 animated film *Bhai Taru Singh* (directed by Vismaad Singh, educating youth on Sikh history).
Influences global Sikh activism, e.g., campaigns by United Sikhs for religious accommodations.

achievements.title: Martyrdom for Faith
achievements.description: Sacrificed life refusing conversion, upholding Sikh articles of faith (kesh); cursed persecutor, leading to his demise per lore.

achievements.title: Sustainer of Khalsa
achievements.description: Provided aid to hundreds of Sikh fighters, ensuring survival during persecution.

achievements.title: Inspiration for Memorial
achievements.description: Led to establishment of Shahid Ganj Gurdwara, a pilgrimage site symbolizing Sikh endurance.

timeline.event: Born in Poohla village to Bhai Jodh Singh and Bibi Dharam Kaur.
Joins Khalsa after witnessing Sikh rescue of a girl from Mughals; begins farming and aiding Sikhs.
Secretly supplies food/clothes to Sikh fighters in jungles amid Zakaria Khan's campaigns.
Arrested by informant Akil Das; sister freed by villagers, but Taru refuses pardon.
Scalped publicly in Lahore; refuses conversion.
Passes away in prison after outliving tormentor Zakaria Khan.
Bhangi Sikhs conquer site; Gurdwara Shaheed Bhai Taru Singh built.

historicalContext.period: Early 18th century (Mughal-Sikh conflicts, post-Guru Gobind Singh era).
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Under Zakaria Khan's governorship (1726‚Äì1745), Mughals launched genocidal campaigns against Sikhs, offering rewards for captures, banning Sikh practices, and forcing conversions to curb the growing Khalsa threat to imperial control.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Sikhs, especially Khalsa members, were hunted as rebels; farming, trade, and worship were restricted, leading to famine and exile. Rural Jatt communities like Taru Singh's faced economic hardship but upheld communal solidarity through langar (community kitchen) and mutual aid.
historicalContext.significance: Taru Singh's martyrdom highlighted Sikh resilience during the "Sikh Holocausts" (e.g., Chhota Ghallughara, 1746). It fueled the Sikh Misls' rise, leading to Punjab's independence by 1799, and symbolizes anti-oppression ethos in Sikhism.
